message.content: We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The symptoms of vomiting, jaundice, and low glucose suggest galactosemia. Among the options, only aldolase B deficiency results in an accumulation of toxic levels of galactose-1-phosphate.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The symptoms of vomiting, jaundice, and dry mucous membranes suggest galactosemia. Among the enzyme deficiencies listed, only Aldolase B is associated with galactosemia. Galactokinase and Galactose-1 phosphate uridyltransferase are associated with galactosemia, but do not typically present with the same symptoms. Glucose-6-phosphatase deficiency is associated with glycogen storage diseases, which typically present with hypoglycemia and hepatomegaly but not jaundice.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The symptoms and lab results suggest galactosemia, and among the options, only Aldolase B is involved in the metabolism of galactose. Galactokinase deficiency would cause only cataracts and no liver symptoms. Galactose-1 phosphate uridyltransferase deficiency would cause hemolysis and nervous system symptoms. Glucose-6-phosphatase deficiency would cause hypoglycemia unrelated to galactosemia.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The symptoms and lab results suggest that the most likely diagnosis is hereditary fructose intolerance, which is caused by a deficiency in aldolase B enzyme. Galactokinase deficiency leads to galactosemia and galactose-1 phosphate uridyltransferase deficiency leads to classic galactosemia, but neither of these conditions fits the symptoms and lab results presented. Glucose-6-phosphatase deficiency leads to glycogen storage disease type I, but this also does not fit the symptoms and lab results presented.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The symptoms suggested galactosemia, which can be caused by a deficiency in galactokinase or galactose-1 phosphate uridyltransferase. However, the high serum AST and ALT levels suggest that the deficient enzyme is aldolase B, which is involved in fructose metabolism.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The symptoms and lab results suggest galactosemia, and among the options, only Aldolase B deficiency causes galactosemia. The other deficiencies cause other types of metabolic disorders.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The symptoms and lab values suggest hereditary fructose intolerance, which is caused by a deficiency in aldolase B. Galactokinase deficiency causes galactosemia, galactose-1 phosphate uridyltransferase deficiency causes classic galactosemia, and glucose-6-phosphatase deficiency causes glycogen storage disease type I.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The symptoms and laboratory findings suggest that the most likely diagnosis is hereditary fructose intolerance. Among the options, the enzyme deficient in hereditary fructose intolerance is aldolase B. Galactokinase deficiency causes galactokinase deficiency galactosemia, Galactose-1 phosphate uridyltransferase deficiency causes Classic galactosemia, and Glucose-6-phosphatase deficiency causes Von Gierke's disease.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The symptoms and lab results suggest the patient has hereditary fructose intolerance (HFI). Among the options, only Aldolase B deficiency causes HFI, leading to vomiting and jaundice when fructose is ingested. Galactokinase deficiency may cause cataracts but not liver dysfunction. Galactose-1 phosphate uridyltransferase deficiency causes galactosemia. Glucose-6-phosphatase deficiency causes glycogen storage disease type I.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The symptoms and laboratory findings are consistent with hereditary fructose intolerance, which is caused by a deficiency of aldolase B. Galactokinase deficiency causes galactosemia, while Galactose-1 phosphate uridyltransferase deficiency causes classic galactosemia. Glucose-6-phosphatase deficiency causes glycogen storage disease type I.
